Merged the latest change of master branch.
Changed test cases that used `count(âstore_salesâ)` to use `count(*)` for instead.
Also, because count(column name) will not be pushed into DruidQuery ([CALC-1805](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-1805)), `avg(column name)` will not be pushed into DruidQuery too, so test cases on Average function cannot be related to post aggregator.
In [test case for AVG function](https://github.com/axeisghost/calcite/blob/post_aggs/druid/src/test/java/org/apache/calcite/test/DruidAdapterIT.java#L2309), a mock-up average function (even it is technically wrong) that can be pushed in will be tested.

Thanks, @jcamachor 
Your concern is right. I just reconsidered the logic in DruidRule. Some of them is redundant and yes I should keep the expression that will be parsed into Post aggregation in the rels and then do the JSON object rendering after the planning.
I chose to render all JSON in the planning place because checking whether the RexNode can be pushed or not will be recursively checking all operation in the RexNode and then rendering of JSON is also recursive. It is able to do it together. However, the encapsulation of solution is a greater concern here. I am changing the solution now.
Thanks for the comment

I user Flink-TableAPI, and come across a NPE,

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5170813/27599676-1ceb1fa2-5b9c-11e7-84b7-73404ad07b44.png)


the existedValue.getValue() returns a null, which cause the NPE, so check if it's null first, then use equals method to compare

See conversation at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-1946.

Well, the validation I proposed first was overly optimistic. The idea was to check that _columns_ argument contains indices of columns that _rel_ can actually provide. But getInputs() is not a good fit for this validation. So proposed different sanity check close to the line where the error actually occurs.

Error occurs at the following line inside _RelMdColumnUniqueness_:
`     
RexNode projExpr = projExprs.get(bit);
`

>Error occurs at the following line inside RelMdColumnUniqueness:
>`RexNode projExpr = projExprs.get(bit);`

It is clear. It is not clear how execution gets there.
What causes `ImmutableBitSet columns` to have more bits than the projected columns?

It happens in _RelBuilder.aggregate(GroupKey groupKey, Iterable<AggCall> aggCalls)_  call upper in stack:

This line:
`final ImmutableBitSet groupSet = ImmutableBitSet.of(registerExpressions(extraNodes, groupKey_.nodes));`
appends **new** nodes to _extraNodes_ collection if there are some expressions besides plain field references in groupKey_.nodes. Corresponding bits are set in _groupSet_.

Then at this line:
`final Boolean unique = mq.areColumnsUnique(peek(), groupSet);` we are trying to check uniqueness of these new columns on the underlying node given by peek() which was not changed (so doesn't and should not contain new columns).

Then I disagree with the fix.

Note theres was `group sets contained expressions not in group key` error: https://github.com/vlsi/calcite/blob/1e7ae1c30a5e6f4335f2e4cc0059f2f2901e35fd/core/src/main/java/org/apache/calcite/tools/RelBuilder.java#L1095

I would rather add an assertion to `org.apache.calcite.rel.metadata.RelMdColumnUniqueness#areColumnsUnique` before `projExprs.get(bit)` to return meaningful error message in case of `ImmutableBitSet columns` is too large.

I think assertion will not fix the problem and given exception already quite specific.

Mentioned error does not disallow expressions in group key, I'd say it assumes that expressions can be in group key and all expressions in group sets (if any) shall be subset of expressions found in group key. For example, it would be natural way of translate such SQL:
`select count(*) from emp group by substring(dept, 0, 5)`

Probably better to apply the fix to RelBuilder.aggregate() then to prevent it to check uniqueness if there are some additional expressions?

Thanks for the contribution!

Can you combine those two commits and title the commit to reference the issue? e.g., `[CALCITE-1987] Implement EXTRACT for JDBC`. In the future, it would also be helpful if you could title PRs this way so it's easier to see what it's for.

+1 from me, when a few comments I made are resolved.

@beikov Can you please commit this when it is ready? Be sure to include the contributor name in parentheses at the end of the first line of the comment (we include names of contributors who are not committers). Re-title the commit to make it as descriptive as possible. Also add "Close apache/calcite#545" in the comment so that ASF's git hook closes the pull request (you & I don't have permission to close this pull request).
Fixed in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-2007.
Thanks for the contribution! Would you be able to rebase this PR into a single commit?

@jcamachor  I think you are suggesting to add testing, right? if yes am planning on adding some, I have sent this PR to get some feedback from the community and to make sure if this is the way to go or there are other alternatives before I start writing tests. FYI I have tested with Hive and it does the trick. Thanks

I was suggesting to change __FilterReduceExpressionsRule__ to call the method _reduceExpressions_ with _matchNullability=false_. Then running the current Calcite testsuite might already provide some valuable feedback (maybe some tests will fail or not, not sure). Additional tests might be added on top of that, sure.

For other subclasses of __ReduceExpressionsRule_, I do not think _matchNullability_ can be set to false at least for the time being, since the planner checks the nullability of the expressions produced by the rules. But you took care of that by passing _true_ by default.

@jcamachor are you suggestion turning off matching nullability by default for the `FilterReduceExpressionsRule` class? FYI i have run the tests with  `matchNullability=false` and all the tests passed. But still unsure if turning it off by default is the way to go.  I guess a broader question will be when you want it on and when you want it off, can you please elaborate around that?

Yes, that was my suggestion, turning it off by default for ```FilterReduceExpressionsRule```.

Turning it off by default for other rules might cause issues in the planner : we had a similar discussion a few days ago in CALCITE-2026 . Basically the planner checks whether the row type of an operator produced by a rule is equal to the row type of the operator that was matched by the rule, including nullability. We were discussing whether it would make sense to lift that restriction, but till we do that, we should not turn it off by default for rules such as ```ProjectReduceExpressionsRule``` or we might run into that AssertionError. Does that make sense?
Reviewers: let's keep this PR open until there is something more substantial. I support fixing javadoc (it's about total quality) but let's not do lots of small commits.

I think that most tests are against the syntax FETCH/MAX ROWS.... and not LIMIT, so I used only that flavour in tests.

SqlPrettyWriter does not insert a space between '?' and "ROWS", I left it unchanged.

The test fails on `JDK7` build. But Apache Geode supports only `Java 8+`!
Can we exclude the Geode adapter from `JDK7` build/release?

I'm not too familiar with Druid, but does this mean the adapter will fail to work with older versions of Druid? If so, we should find some way to maintain backwards compatibility.

version 0.15.0 of adapter will work with 0.10.0 druid version. 
After the update newer calcite releases will support and will be tested with druid 0.11.0 version.

Users are expected to update druid first and then move to newer adapter version.
